repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Power and Communication Sectors
            Modernization and Rural Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Power and Communication
            Sector Modernization and Rural Services Project
            (PROMEC's) in Ecuador were as follows: overall outcome
            of the project was rated moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, and the performance of the
            Bank and the Borrower were rated as moderately satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project are: 1) the project
            included a wide range of components that spanned six
            different implementing agencies. One could argue that this
            breadth proved unwieldy and made the job of the project unit
            extremely difficult. It also resulted in delays because of
            the large number of coordination agreements required. Each
            change of government necessitated rebuilding relationships
            and convincing new leadership of the Project's
            validity. However, on the other hand, the involvement of a
            large number of implementing agencies that felt that the
            Project activities were useful meant that the Project had
            solid and continuous support in the Government; and 2)
            communication and community participation approach highly
            beneficial. PROMEC's communication and participation
            activities were considered by participants to be innovative,
            important and highly beneficial. The benefits were multiple:
            (a) helping create awareness of Project activities; (b)
            building consensus on implementation approaches; (c)
            building capacity of communities and individuals to
            participate in design and implementation; and, perhaps most
            importantly, (d) increasing accountability and transparency
            of the Project's activities and management to
            stakeholders. All of these factors contributed to the
            generally positive perception of the Project.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Power and Communications Sectors
            Modernization and Rural Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Power and Communications Sectors
            Modernization and Rural Services Project aims at deepening
            reforms in the telecommunications, and electricity sectors,
            by strengthening regulatory institutions, and improving
            environmental management of the sectors' activities,
            fostering competition, and increasing private participation,
            promoting efficient use of energy, and providing new
            information and communication technologies (IT) to support
            services to micro, and small businesses. The components
            will: 1) strengthen the legal and regulatory frameworks in
            telecommunications, and electricity. Public consultations,
            and dissemination of regulatory decisions will be undertaken
            to supervise, and strengthen the Telecommunications Agency
            (SUPTEL), while software programs, and equipment will be
            financed, and a telecommunications tariff rebalancing plan
            prepared. Electricity regulations of the National Council of
            Electricity will be completed, including strengthening its
            institutional capacity, and monitoring criteria, and that of
            other sector institutions. Selected energy, and tariff
            studies will support these activities; 2) extend services to
            low income groups, and small businesses in peri-urban areas,
            by developing pilot projects, an electrification strategy
            (both grid-extension and off-grid), revising IT regulations,
            and, developing IT access in marginal urban, and rural
            areas; 3) design, and implement a program to promote the
            use, and conservation of electricity, to include tariff
            incentives, standards for efficient electrical appliances,
            public information, and, market assessment, and training to
            local energy service companies; and, 4) finance project
            management, consultation, and communications activities to
            provide support to implementing agencies, and the private sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Power and Communications Sectors
            Modernization and Rural Services Project :  environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental and social assessment
            for the Ecuador Power and Communications Sectors
            Modernization and Rural Services Project anticipates likely
            negative environmental impacts and proposes measures to
            mitigate them. This report also analyzes the effectiveness
            of the environmental legislation for the energy and
            telecommunications sectors related to the project
            components, and discusses ways to strengthen policies and
            the institutional capacity for environmental management.
            Major impacts due to the internal combustion associated with
            thermoelectric generation are emissions of nitrous oxide and
            monoxide. Other potential impacts are significant water
            pollution, leakage of hydrocarbons, inadequate solid waste
            disposal, and noise affecting workers as well as neighboring
            populations. Potential impacts associated with hydroelectric
            generation include the deterioration in quantity of water
            resources, that is interrupted water flow, reduced water
            availability and regularity for use by the general
            population; a deterioration in water quality because of the
            excessive production of nutrients leading to anaerobic
            conditions., loss of the vegetal cover and acceleration of
            erosion caused by reservoirs and civil works, and increased
            noise and vibrations caused by machinery and equipment which
            would not only affect neighboring populations but the also
            the health of workers. Recommended mitigation measures to
            offset these impacts include devising policies to reduce
            emissions--in particular adhering to provisions of the Kyoto
            Accord, and relying on domestic agencies concerned with
            insuring environmentally sustainable development, as well as
            promoting use of renewable energy resources. Negative
            impacts likely to arise from energy transmission comprise
            destruction of forest and biodiversity, and interference
            with protected area management and fragile ecosystems
            because of transmission lines and installations, as well as
            reduced access to areas where theses structures are located,
            increased solid waste generation, electromagnetic radiation
            from transmission lines affecting humans and animal species,
            and a reduced right-of-way.
